newsitem.title: INDIA: India hopes to play host to 5 mln tourists by 2000.
newsitem.headline: India hopes to play host to 5 mln tourists by 2000.

text.p: India intends to give a strong boost to its tourist trade by the turn of the century, Tourism Minister Srikanta Kumar Jena said on Saturday.

"We plan to double the number of foreign tourists from the 2.3 million in 1996/97 (April-March) to more than five million by the year 2000," he told reporters in a briefing on a draft of national tourism policy.

Ministry officials said the government proposed meeting the target by removing visa restrictions, cutting red tape for the inbound travellers and by giving bilateral and unilateral concessions to certain countries.
The minister said that tourism was India's single biggest foreign exchange earner in the year 1996/97 (April-March), bringing in $3.1 billion.
"We plan to cater to the middle-income traveller, and encourage smaller hotels, motels and roadside facilities," Jena said.
Domestic tourism was also a big force that needs to be addressed with better facilities, the minister said. In 1996/97, there were about 141 million domestic tourists.
M.P. Bezbaruah, secretary of the department of tourism, said the improvement of the existing facilities and better marketing would enable the department to meet some of its targets.
"Image building of India is one major exercise that we are focusing on," Bezbaruah said.
Foreign tourists and tour operators say India's weak infrastructure puts a huge bottleneck in the development of country as a major tourist destination.
India's current share in the world tourist traffic is less than 0.4 percent, a Tourism Ministry paper said.

"Considering the dimensions of the country and the multitude of attractions it possesses, the potential of India in attracting international tourists is yet to be realised," the ministry said in its study draft.
Jena said he welcomed the entry of foreign capital in the sector. "Multinationals are welcome to come and invest in the infrastructure, build hotels and make roads," he said.

He said the ministry, in its estimates, submitted to the Planning Commission, had said the country needs nearly 480 billion rupees in the next five year plan (1997-2002) to spruce up its creaking tourism-related infrastructure.
"Investment in aviation, roads, railways, ports and accommodation will facilitate tourist traffic," the minister said.
